assessment.message: Speaking pace is good for presentation

recommendations: Work on maintaining consistent speaking pace throughout your presentation.
Practice with a metronome or pacing exercises to develop rhythm.
Reduce excessive pausing. Practice speaking with more confidence and fluency.
Use longer strategic pauses to give audience time to process important information.
Use pauses after key points to let information sink in.
Work on maintaining consistent voicing throughout speech

filler_detection.transcript: First of all, the Introduce Massage from Hasim Aqed at Minimum, New York, Wietersen, and Sweden. Our Graduation Project is about mock interview assessment. Basically, you give it a job description and it makes an interview or an assessment for you by extracting the important keywords like four years of experience, skills that should be like Python, S++ and so on. It makes an interview or assessment for you. And then,
recommendations: Reduce filler words - practice pausing instead of saying 'um' or 'uh'
Pay special attention to your use of 'like'
Work on reducing excessive pauses - practice smooth transitions
Practice speaking with a steady rhythm and pace

stutter_detection.assessment: Significant stuttering detected, speech therapy recommended
recommendations: Practice speaking at a slower pace, especially during presentations
Use relaxation techniques before speaking engagements
Consider joining a speech improvement group or workshop
Focus on maintaining steady breathing while speaking
Focus on the 3 segments where stuttering was detected
Try to smile more and show positive facial expressions
Allow for some natural pauses in gesturing to avoid appearing overly animated.
You use 'counting' gestures effectively. Continue incorporating similar movements.

presentation_insights.strength: Strong use of counting gestures shows good presentation instincts
presentation_insights.improvement: Excellent gesture usage, maintain this standard
presentation_insights.engagement: High gesture frequency suggests strong audience engagement potential

recommendations: Give your arms space to move naturally
Practice gestures that extend slightly away from your body
Stand tall with shoulders back and chest open
Imagine a string pulling you up from the top of your head
Practice good posture daily to make it habitual
Avoid hands on hips - it can appear confrontational or impatient
Use more specific and technical vocabulary related to your topic
Use more content words and fewer filler words
